title: Wednesday, 7th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Good morning. Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever.

BE11:06am

And as we'll be on election broadcasting rules tomorrow, this is the last opportunity.

BE11:06am

So .... Let's get this over with.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Tinhat

BE11:06am

We stand on the brink of the most important General Election in the history of our history, before or since. Its outcome will have a profound effect on all our futures for decades, centuries, millenniums or millennia I haven't checked the style guide yet. Your vote will not just define our standing in the world -- it will shape our very definition of what it means to be British. Use it wisely.

BE11:06am

Yet in contrast to the gravity of the juncture at which our proud nation stands, the choices presented to our electorate are whatever the opposite of gravity is. A vacuum, is it? Because we face a leadership vacuum. Britain is flying into storm that stretches from domestic to international airspace, at an altitude where the air of democratic process is dangerously thin, and none of the potential pilots on offer has set out a flight path that will guide us back to the airport of economic security and the Duty Free of steady productivity growth.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

In short, no party has put forward a manifesto deserving of our unqualified endorsement, the dicks.

BE11:07am

That is why Markets Live urges readers to vote for whichever candidate makes them feel more like buying an FT premium subscription.

BE11:07am

---- https://sub.ft.com/ ----

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Some may see this endorsement as self interest. To them, we say: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

BE11:07am

I mean, since when do you expect news media to operate out of anything other than unvarnished self interest? Jeez. Haven't you noticed? Our industry's knackered!

BE11:07am

Just look at the evidence. It is an ineluctable truth that the Markets Live staff headcount is down 50% year on year. We must reverse this trend -- but One Southwark Bridge has no magic money tree. Investment is required to maintain our stong and stable back-end CMS, and to somehow convince advertisers that Markets Live is a forum for the many, not the few.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Our nation stands on a precipice. It is a precipice on the crossroads at the brink of a juncture. But in this election you have an opportunity to deliver a clear message to those that seek to lead us through it. And the clearest message you can deliver today is to give us £14.50 per week (£8.16 digital only). https://sub.ft.com/

BE11:08am

Tinhat

undefined
11:08 am
BE11:08am

So anyway, we're now in countdown to Triple Threat Thursday.

BE11:08am

General Election, ECB meeting and Comey’s Senate testimony

BE11:08am

Unfortunately, that countdown puts us square in in the middle of No News Wednesday.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

There's zip this morning. Nil. Nowt.

BE11:09am

I mean, there's lots of election strategy if you want that.

BE11:10am

Citi has a quant analysis of elections past, which is an impressive work of statistical number crunching yet is likely to be almost entirely useless.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Here are the numbers.

BE11:10am

BE11:11am

(Right click and open in new window to enlarge. Yeah, we don't have the facility to do that natively here.)

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Also Citi, here are some words.

BE11:11am

The UK General Election this week will be the 20th since 1945. There have been 9 majority victories for the Conservative party, 9 also (including one minority government) for the Labour party and one Coalition government.

BE11:11am

On average, UK shares have performed worse than average rolling returns since 1945 in the 3- and 6-months following the previous 19 elections. Average 12-month returns following elections has seen UK equities return an average 14.6% versus a rolling average since 1945 of 13.4%.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

UK equity markets have historically been stronger in the 3-months ahead and after elections with a Conservative victory, but average 12-month returns have been stronger in the case of Labour victory, although skewed by 100%+ following the second 1974 election. We would argue that 6-12 month equity market performance will have been often driven by factors and trends away from domestic UK politics, eg global economic recession/recovery, oil crisis, conflict, global profit cycle etc. This election could play a significant role in driving the direction and dynamics of UK equity markets in the coming months and even years. We think this outcome needs a Labour-led government. This would likely bring a more aggressive downside reaction from GBP as well as bringing greater Brexit uncertainty (including perhaps the risk of no Brexit eventually), nationalization risk, higher corporate taxes and greater headwinds for UK banks all onto the debate card for UK equity investors. Citi’s base case remains, however, a majority win for the Conservative party; in this scenario we expect little significant change from across financial markets.

BE11:13am

Remember having to write something along those lines for Bloomberg, to please an American editor who wanted to know whether markets perform better under Tory or Labour governments. My reply -- "I could spend a week answering that, but it's a dumb question" -- wasn't really appreciated.

BE11:13am

Anyway, have ING on sterling as well.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

The last-minute tightening of polls means that this election now draws greater parallels to the 2015 general election, as well as the recent Presidential elections in the US and France. In all 3 cases, the currency reacted positively as the event risk passed and political uncertainty faded. This could be the playbook for GBP if we get the status quo of a Conservative majority. To get a meaningful move higher in GBP, we still think that Mrs. May will need to extend her majority to at least 50 – and realistically a lot closer to a 100. This could take GBP/$ to 1.32.

BE11:14am

Yet, it’s not that simple anymore and the worst case for sterling come Friday morning – is a hung parliament. Maximum chaos would be if the Conservatives were only able to get somewhere between 290 to 325 seats; it’s the grey area where it’s not enough for a Conservative majority, but also potentially not enough to see a stable Labour-led coalition being formed quickly. Uncertainty is the pound’s well-known Achilles' Heel and in a hung parliament scenario, we think it could fall to 1.24 against the dollar. Equally, it may be tempting to draw parallels to a Corbyn GBP relief rally and what was observed in the USD after President Trump was elected (where the initial sell-off was quickly reversed). Yet, we would stipulate that a stable coalition would need to be formed before one can start making any sweeping assumptions about changes to Brexit policy.

undefined
11:15 am
BE11:15am

I'll get to RPC, ROTR! No one could be more interested in extruded plastics than I!

BE11:15am

First, though, @DutchBrat mentions Santander.

BE11:16am

Buying Popular.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Well, rescuing really. Unless you count a €1 price tag as buying.

BE11:18am

There's a €7bn rights issue to cover shipping onboard all of Popular's rubbish, which makes the deal neutral both for CET1 and earnings per share for the next few years at least.

BE11:19am

Accretive by 2% in 2019, though that's based on cutting a third! of Popular's cost base by 2020.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Credit Suisse incoming.

BE11:19am

The deal makes strategic sense for SAN which will gain market share in Spain and SME, diluting its emerging markets contribution to earnings. Further revenue synergies (€100-200m) not included at plan could improve the deal’s ROI of 13%-14%. In 2017 SAN could take a hit in terms of stated earnings, however, as flagged in our recent report the current acquisition conditions are the best deal for SAN.

BE11:20am

And Barclays, fresh off the conference call.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

We see the high level of provision coverage on Popular and reasonable synergy expectations as key areas of support for Santander’s expectations that its acquisition can be 3% EPS accretive and generate a 13-14% RoI. The company’s capital position remains adequate and although it’s below most other European banks, the Popular acquisition should aid organic capital generation in time. Although most concerns are largely addressed, execution and litigation remain areas of uncertainty. We rate Santander Overweight.

BE11:20am

Key targets for the Popular acquisition - €1bn more net profit for a €7bn capital increase

Accretive - Accretive to earnings 3% (2020), tNAV 3% (2018) and 13-14% ROI (2020) which is a €1bn net profit target for Popular.

At least capital neutral - €7bn rights issue to be completed over next 2 months means the CET1 ratio will be neutral to slightly positive.

Addressing the €34bn real estate book - Coverage of Popular’s non-performing assets will be increased to 67% (vs peer average 52%) with the €30bn real estate portfolio targeted to be reduced by 50% in the next 18 months and fully unwound by 2020.

Synergies – Targeting €500m cost synergies which is equivalent to 10% of the combined 2017 cost base or 33% of Popular’s costs. Santander assumes 9% revenue attrition compared to Popular consensus.

BE11:22am

So .... Big, complicated and lightly capitalised bank does a shotgun rescue of a peer that expands its balance sheet by about 10% and involves a baffling array of provisions.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

And the numbers only make sense based on removing a third of said bank without any kind of operational impact.

BE11:23am

That kind of thing usually goes pretty well, right?

BE11:23am

Have Kepler as well.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

The fact that Santander has had only a few days to carry out due diligence on the real estate exposures and bad loans at Popular (over EUR36bn), as well as other potential risks and the costs involved in breaking up the joint ventures also generates doubts about whether the measurement of risks has been adequate. We also do not know the amount of deposits lost since 31 March, but we assume it has been substantial (we guess 5-10%), given that it has required a quick intervention by resolution authorities.

BE11:24am

The combined entity will lose market share, given that SMEs need to diversify their lending sources and Santander is already strong in SMEs. Furthermore, we are doubtful that Popular is an easy-to-integrate bank, given its “different” risk management (higher risk SME lending/higher margins based on relationship banking).

BE11:25am

They've gone to hold from buy.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

The investment thesis of low risk add-on acquisitions, focus on TBVPS, EPS and DPS growth and organic capital accumulation changes after this high-risk acquisition.

BE11:25am

It certainly does.

undefined
11:25 am
BE11:25am

While on banks, best note the British ones.

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 257.77, up 6.07 (+2.41%), High: 258.40, Low: 252.00, Volume: 3.52m
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 70.26, up 1.32 (+1.91%), High: 70.33, Low: 68.57, Volume: 48.68m
11:26 am
BE11:26am

The former we can attribute at least partly to the settlement news midway through yesterday.

BE11:27am

https://www.ft.com...-ada5-bbceff6696ec

BE11:27am

Investec welcomes the (probable) removal of an overhang.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Prior to yesterday’s settlement, RBS had already reached an agreement with 87% (by value) of claims in relation to the 2008 Shareholder Rights Issue litigation, at a cost of c.£0.7bn. A final settlement on equivalent terms would have cost £0.1bn, at 82p a share, the cost is now £0.2bn and so, after legal costs of c.£0.1bn, the final bill should come to a cool £1bn.
On 28 April, RBS reported a materially better-than-expected Q1 2017 performance, albeit “flattered” by (1) lower Non-core losses and (2) a particularly strong contribution from NatWest Markets, with revenues of £508m up 83% YoY. We do assume that this will prove to be a “never-to-be-repeated” high watermark for NWM, but even so, the contribution is helpful.

BE11:27am

On a more sustainable basis, we draw comfort from both (1) RBS continuing rapid progress on cost take-out; at a group level, costs fell by £0.3bn (-15% YoY) to £1.8bn and (2) RBS’ decision to “fill its boots” on TFS. After an initial reluctance to participate, RBS took £5bn in Q4 2016 and a further £9bn in Q1 2017, making it the single biggest user. We have little doubt that this £14bn of 4-year money at 25bps can be substituted or deployed to good effect as RBS manages its liabilities more broadly, and sustains quite rapid “core” growth.
The Attributable Profit of £0.3bn achieved in Q1 2017 was after an “accelerated” £0.6bn of restructuring charges. As such, we now model a £0.5bn Attributable Profit in Q2 2017 before the losses resume in H2 2017e.
Material conduct risks and uncertainties remain, but on 0.8x Q1 2017 tNAV (297p) we upgrade to Hold (from Sell) and raise our TP to 260p (from 240p).

undefined
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Plastics, then.

BE11:31am

BE11:05am

It was pointed out to me earlier today that ML hasn't yet endorsed a General Election candidate.

11:31 am
RPC Group PLC (RPC:LSE): Last: 830.00, down 20 (-2.35%), High: 885.00, Low: 788.00, Volume: 3.65m
BE11:32am

FY ahead of consensus, though remember they said on March 30 that it would be.

BE11:32am

Adjusted EBITA at £308m. Consensus was around the £295m mark.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Revenues in line or perhaps slightly light at £2,75bn, organic growth of 3%.

BE11:34am

So, it's a margin story. Early completion of Letica etc plus cost cut and polymer headwinds fading a bit.

BE11:35am

No change in 2018 guidance, which is possibly disappointing given the above.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Here comes Jefferies.

BE11:35am

Post recent de-rating, RPC trades at discount to both international plastic packaging rivals: Amcor, Aptar and Berry Global and traditional UK
packaging peers: DS Smith, Mondi & Smurfit Kappa, despite offering 3% organic growth,
full year contribution of recent M&A and synergies. Believe improved RPC disclosure and guidance on FY18 restructuring costs can catalyse re-rating.

BE11:36am

RPC trades on FY18 12.8x PE & 8.2x EV/EBITDA, for 8% FY17-20 EPS CAGR: a discount to
both international plastic packaging rivals & UK packaging peers. Risks: 1) M&A execution/
integration; 2) FX; 3) Polymer prices. With confidence in underlying trading and enhanced
RPC disclosure: Reaffirm Buy with £11.50 PT (based on FY18F 10.2x EV/EBITDA), set by reference to global plastic packaging peers Amcor, Aptar, and Berry Global.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

And Panmure.

BE11:36am

In recent years RPC management has been pushing the business hard, driving industry leading organic growth and a steady stream of acquisitions. FY17 results highlight both the benefits and shortfalls of this policy. Revenues and earnings are materially ahead (up 67% and 77% respectively). Indeed margins better than 33 basis points expected. However, non-recurring items remain high (£131m) and cash conversion remains weak (70% on PG basis). But it must be noted that cash generation is better than expected. Which set of metrics you choose to focus on will determine your view on the stock. Following the Letica acquisition the bears had clearly been winning. Though in recent weeks, a more balanced view had prevailed and the shares had begun to recover. This morning’s results provide something for both the bulls and the bears but overall we believe the shares will move higher.

BE11:38am

You'll remember Northern Trust led the bear attack on RPC. Spin back to late March for a reminder of that.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Haven't seen anything yet from Northern Trust's Paul Moran this morning.

BE11:39am

He did get a quick punch in pre today's numbers though.

BE11:40am

Management countered some of our points raised, especially on raw materials pass-through, which given our very limited data cf. management’s information, we concede management is in a far better place to judge trends than we are on this issue. However our points on falling returns, aggressive FCF definitions (and what seem to be errors), LTIP awards and cash provision leakage were not countered. After further work and comparison with other plastic packagers, there are two areas where RPC seems to stand out – a relatively high capex/sales ratio vs peers and consistent cash provision charges from its acquisitions – this is in addition to clear restructuring costs. These are two areas we believe deserve more scrutiny.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Management has confirmed the cash provision charges will continue, with the majority of the balance of provisions on the balance sheet resulting in cash charges in future. Obviously, post the seven additional acquisitions that were closed since the Sep-16 balance sheet was published, we await an updated balance of provisions. With respect to capex/sales (7% average of last 3Y vs peers 3-5%) management explains this is investment in the plant in order to get higher growth. We don’t quite understand this rationale, i.e. a much greater capital intensity for a few percentage points of extra growth vs peers, especially when the growth mostly comes from acquisitions. We wonder if the plant is simply older v peers or if there is some capitalisation of cost occurring.

BE11:40am

In this regard, it was interesting to note in the rights issue prospectus associated with the acquisition of Letica (and other smaller businesses) there was no history of capex/sales given (usually given for acquisition targets), nor was a figure given when we asked for it. The (adjusted) EBITDA figure of $57M for the Jun-16 year for Letica included a significant amount of “capitalization of certain costs” ($21M, see prospectus for details), which meant the reported EBITDA after other items were taken into account was actually $38M. Two things became immediately apparent to us: given the cost capitalization, capex certainly is an important metric; and the headline EV/EBITDA multiple of 8.5x is actually 12.8x using unadjusted EBITDA.

BE11:40am

We think the Letica acquisition itself exemplifies how valuing RPC solely on adjusted EPS or EV/EBITDA is overly optimistic. It’s not just that there are consistent cash restructuring charges (ignored in adjusted EPS), or cash provision charges (also not in adjusted EPS), the capex/sales is and has been consistently high over time. Until capex approaches depreciation or until such time provision/restructuring charges disappear, FCF should be the metric of choice we think. This is particularly true of a business that has consistently raised equity to make acquisitions, well in excess of the dividend that gets paid.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Of course, heading into FY17 numbers, when there have been seven acquisitions since the last report, forecasting FCF is difficult. We are expecting about £120M in FCF for FY17 (and c.£180M for FY18) for a market cap of c.£3.6B, a 3.3% and 5% FCF yield which is a premium to peers. H1 was significantly boosted by working capital inflows of £29M (FCF was £66M in H1), something management guided would be the case and more is due, but these are one-off in nature. Restructuring charges have at least another £60M to go we think over the next two years. What is more important is the underlying cash generation of the existing business and acquisitions AFTER provisions and other cash charges are taken into account. In our view, the cash generation has been surprisingly low. FY17 numbers will be a test of management’s diligence in allocating shareholders’ equity in the last 12 months, as well as our own bearish stance.

BE11:42am

Polarised.

undefined
11:44 am
BE11:44am

Okay, so what else? If it weren't for the election I suspect our comment count would be in the 5-10 region today.

BE11:47am

The only thing I've seen DPL related is from Canaccord, which has a sector thing out on the builders' merchants.

Howden Joinery Group PLC (HWDN:LSE): Last: 456.50, up 15.5 (+3.51%), High: 456.50, Low: 444.90, Volume: 1.31m
11:47 am
Travis Perkins PLC (TPK:LSE): Last: 1,598, up 32 (+2.04%), High: 1,601, Low: 1,584, Volume: 329.13k
BE11:49am

............ and which is taking an extraordinarily long time to open.

BE11:49am

Oh -- it's a 6.8mb PDF. That'll be why. Don't they realise we still use Vic 20s here?

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Bif. There we go. 127 pages of it.

BE11:50am

The outlook for the UK Merchants is mixed.

BE11:50am

Thumbs up

11:50 am
BE11:50am

UK trading conditions are currently
challenging with significant cost inflation; H1 results are expected to be muted. There
are also differences in performance between end-markets (e.g., Plumbing vs Heavyside
& Consumer vs Trade). However, in the longer term, we see good UK demand drivers
supported by an ageing housing stock, an under-supply of housing and public housing
declines easing. We continue to believe that the majors will outperform their markets
as they benefit from structural advantages (buying power, superior IT and supply
chains). Key overseas markets are performing relatively well. Balance sheets are
generally in sound shape with average leverage comfortably below 1 times. The recently
disappointing operational leverage and free-cash-flow generation should improve over
the medium term as the industry has invested significantly in the last few years. While we
remain cautious and selective near term, the UK economy is holding up relatively well,
consensus expectations are undemanding and the sector has levers to pull if trading
worsens. Looking further out, we see a sub-sector that looks relatively well positioned
from a macro and micro standpoint to improve margins and returns and deliver value to
shareholders.

BE11:50am

Recently, margins, returns and free-cash generation have been generally disappointing
and 2017 is likely to be similar. Wolseley has been the exception, driven by a strong
US business. We expect margins and earnings growth to improve in 2018 assuming a
relatively flat RM&I market, no UK recession and no step up in cost inflation. Longer
term, we believe margins and returns have material upside. Leverage continues to fall.

BE11:50am

The sector has delivered a good 5 year TSR (CAGR of c.+11%), but has been less
impressive over recent years. The sector trades on a 2018E PE of around 14.5 times
and an EV:Sales of c.0.85 times, which are broadly in line with average multiples, but on
subdued UK estimates. Dividend yield is not overly attractive at c.2.5%.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Stock wise ..............

BE11:51am

Eurocell (BUY, TP 295p) - Strong impetus for growth from new management team.
Significant capacity to grow sales and profits above the market. Strong balance sheet.
Grafton (HOLD, TP 810p) - Ireland strong with a more mixed performance in UK. Scope
to continue to improve margins and returns. Valuation looks relatively full.
Howdens (BUY, TP 500p) - More exposed to consumer and weaker sterling but strong
business. Net cash and share buyback. Medium-term value opportunity.
SIG (HOLD, TP 150p) - Turnaround. Good first impression of new management. Returns
look likely to improve. Balance sheet stretched but being addressed.
Travis Perkins (BUY, TP 1,865p) - Strengthening its competitive position. Near-term
headwinds, but low expectations and looks attractively positioned in the longer term.
Wolseley (HOLD, TP 5,400p) - US exposure boosting performance and we expect this will
continue to be a driver of value creation over the medium term.

Eurocell PLC (ECEL:LSE): Last: 261.40, up 1.4 (+0.54%), Volume: 24.99k
11:51 am
Howden Joinery Group PLC (HWDN:LSE): Last: 456.70, up 15.7 (+3.56%), High: 456.80, Low: 444.90, Volume: 1.32m
SIG PLC (SHI:LSE): Last: 150.40, up 2.1 (+1.42%), High: 151.20, Low: 148.00, Volume: 758.67k
Wolseley PLC (WOS:LSE): Last: 5,010, up 19 (+0.38%), High: 5,035, Low: 4,950, Volume: 193.86k
11:52 am
BE11:52am

Oh, and Goodbody also, which says the sector's looking a bit stretched.

BE11:53am

Since the EU referendum, underlying activity levels in the UK construction sector and merchanting segment have held up better than we expected, which was incorporated into our estimates post recent trading statements. Therefore, the only forecast changes in this note are for the brick companies. However, the more forward indicators remain weak and are expected to deteriorate on the back of uncertainty around the General Election and Brexit. In addition, we believe the full force of real wage pressures has yet to be felt, which could put further pressures on end markets, especially the rmi market where there is limited government support, unlike new residential and infrastructure.

BE11:53am

As a result, we continue to anticipate lfls to soften for the merchants in H2 and nto 2018. Breedon Group will benefit from a pick-up in infrastructure, while the Brick companies have favourable industry dynamics.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

An examination of current multiples across the sector show that current levels are close to +1 standard deviation from the historical average. Against a backdrop of uncertainty and weak forward indicators, such valuations look stretched.

BE11:54am

Travis goes back to "sell", Grafton, Breedon and Forterra are the only buys.

BE11:55am

That's from Robert Eason, who's good. And his sector PDF is only 30 pages, vs 127 from Canaccord. You can choose yourself how much you want to read about builders' merchants.

11:55 am
undefined
BE11:56am

(@Flaneur: that's the worst analysis I've ever read, with the exception of the ones I've written.)

BE11:58am

.........so, what else?

11:58 am
BE11:58am

There's Ocado. There's always Ocado.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 300.40, down 8 (-2.59%), High: 309.10, Low: 300.30, Volume: 933.88k
BE11:59am

Post the mysterious sort-of deal and the visit to its Andover shed.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Andrew Gwynn of Exane says, "it's up on this? Are you nuts?"

BE11:59am

(I'm paraphrasing.)

BE11:59am

With little in the way of near-term earnings to value, Ocado’s valuation remains difficult to fully
unpick. We remain of the view that consensus forecasts are far too optimistic (see page 3) and if it
is just about struggling to make the UK food retail business profitable with a couple of small
partnerships, the shares are undoubtedly expensive. In contrast, if Ocado can sign some
international mega partnerships, then maybe there is upside. For us, the weight of evidence
remains to the downside, however, and we would be looking to sell into the recent upward move.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

He enjoyed his day out, which is something.

BE12:00pm

Yesterday, Ocado showed sell-side analysts the third iteration of its picking technology (CFC3). We
were not allowed to take pictures and words do not fully suffice but the group is moving from
conveyor belts to robots picking stacked boxes in a ‘hive’. The technology is not dissimilar to the
‘AutoStore’, though subtly different and to a simple food retail analyst, albeit, one
who has been around Ocado since it IPO’d, it is impressive.

BE12:01pm

But, as nearly two decades of unprofitability shows, neat robot arms aren't enough on their own to build a viable company.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Ocado, however, is not trying to sell the technology and its broader ‘Ocado Smart Platform’ to food retail analysts but rather, food retailers and it remains to be seen if they will sign up. CFC3 was opened about a year later than expected, and seven months in, utilisation is little more than 10%. Further, while we were there, there were frequent ‘pauses’ as the system digested minor gremlins.

BE12:01pm

Getting a partner to sign up to the full-scale end-to-end platform (i.e., with distribution centre) on
the strength of CFC3 might be compared with trying to get a marriage proposal on the basis of an
online dating profile with a picture taken in bad light. It is probably better to go on a few dates first
and test out some of the software – very much like Ocado’s anonymous new European partner is
doing. The problem, however, is twofold; 1) selling software seemingly does not earn Ocado a lot,
and 2) gross profit per basket and delivery costs, not picking, remain the key profit problems.

undefined
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

And that concludes Triple Dull Wednesday.

BE12:05pm

Thanks for joining. Thanks for banging on about the election and ignoring that there's nearly no actual corporate or macro news today.

BE12:06pm

See you back here tomorrow, probably.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:31am

And RPC.
